content: The Act may be cited as the "Update, Promote, and Develop America's Transportation Essentials Act of 2013". Since the passage of SAFETEA-LU, Congress has transferred over $50 billion from the General Fund to the Highway Trust Fund to maintain solvency. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that annual General Fund transfers of approximately $15 billion will be necessary after Fiscal year 2014 to sustain current spending levels. Additionally, an extra $83 billion a year would be needed to fund surface transportation projects with Federal benefits outweighing costs, as estimated by the Congressional Budget Office and the American Society for Civil Engineers. The United States should invest an additional $500 billion in the surface transportation system by 2020. Recommendations include raising the gas tax by fifteen cents and implementing a Federal funding system based on vehicle miles traveled. Congress needs to prevent the Highway Trust Fund from becoming insolvent to maintain infrastructure spending. By 2024, Congress aims to repeal the gas tax and replace it with a more sustainable funding source. Congress aims to repeal the gas tax by 2024 and replace it with a more sustainable funding source, including a tax on motor fuels. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the tax rates for gasoline and diesel fuel. For gasoline other than aviation gasoline, the tax rates are as follows: 18.3 cents per gallon before 2014, 26.3 cents per gallon in 2014, 30.3 cents per gallon in 2015, and 33.3 cents per gallon after 2015 but before 2025. Diesel fuel or kerosene tax rates are also adjusted accordingly. The tax rates for diesel fuel or kerosene are adjusted as follows: 24.3 cents per gallon before 2014, 32.3 cents per gallon in 2014, 36.3 cents per gallon in 2015, and 39.3 cents per gallon after 2015 but before 2025. Additionally, there is an adjustment for inflation in tax rates starting from 2016. The tax rates for diesel fuel or kerosene are adjusted annually based on the cost of living adjustment determined for the calendar year beginning after 2016. The rates are increased by a calculated amount and rounded to the nearest 0.1 cents. Additionally, the rate for Diesel-Water Fuel Emulsion is amended to 71 percent of the original rate. The tax rates for diesel fuel or kerosene are adjusted annually based on the cost of living adjustment. The rate for Diesel-Water Fuel Emulsion is amended to 71 percent of the original rate. Section 4081(d)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to change the termination date to December 31, 2024. These amendments apply to fuels or liquids removed, entered, or sold after December 31, 2013. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code over the tax already paid. Liability and Payment: The person holding the liquid is liable for the tax, to be paid as prescribed by the Secretary within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. The floor stocks tax date is defined as any January 1 of a calendar year after a tax rate increase. Taxable liquid includes diesel fuel and kerosene. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The tax exemptions for taxable liquid include exceptions for fuel held in vehicle tanks and certain amounts of fuel held on the floor stocks tax date, not exceeding 2,000 gallons. Information submission to the Secretary is required for the exemption. Exempt fuel held by any person is not considered for tax purposes if exempt by subsection (d) or (e). Controlled groups are treated as one person, defined by the meaning in section 1563 of the Code with "more than 50 percent" substituted for "at least 80 percent." Under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, principles similar to those of clause (i) apply to a group of persons under common control where one or more are not corporations. All provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 apply to floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) to the same extent.
